body:
Thank you for reporting this to us @hanlaur üôáüèª 

I just looked into it a little bit and it would appear indeed that we apply some JSON serialization over the second argument of the `invoke` call under the hood: https://github.com/grafana/k6/blob/f76cb771fe80d4962095edbd97f0f9baa800c09f/js/modules/k6/grpc/client.go#L360

I assume the JSON marshalling treats `Nan`, `Infinity`, and `-Infinity` as `null` (which I imagine is what JSON is supposed to do), instead of maintaining the expected representation.

cc @olegbespalov

Hi! I was looking into this since I have the same problem. First, I wanted to understand why a null value works for the single float but not for the array. It seems the "problem" is with the `protojson` library:

https://github.com/grafana/k6/blob/613b0ad1b10341579b48ec8dbc81b1b0c1dbb692/lib/netext/grpcext/conn.go#L132-L135

In this code, using the same Proto definition that @hanlaur shared, when we use this input:
```json
{"single_float":null,"array_float":[1, null]}
```

The unmarshaling fails for the value in the array, but works for the single value, even though they are of the same type. I was about to open an issue in the protobuf library, but I just saw [an issue explaining this intended behavior.](https://github.com/golang/protobuf/issues/1313)

So, after that unrelated rant, it seems that the problem is exactly as @oleiade  mentioned üòÇ. I guess the best approach would be to parse `NaN` as "NaN", and similarly for `+/-Infinity` as "+/-Infinity".

I wouldn‚Äôt mind working on this... I assume this would need to be addressed in https://github.com/grafana/sobek, since that's what‚Äôs used to build the message, right?

Thanks!

Pinging @oleiade in case you missed it.
Just wanted to know the status of this or if I can help in any way once I have some free time. üòÉ

Hey @ariasmn üëãüèª 

Apologies, this slid under my radar üôáüèª 

I still don't know what the best approach might be to cater to this, however, I'm pretty certain modifying Sobek isn't an option. If you have capacity, I invite you to look into alternative approaches, and we'd happily review and contribute to a PR üöÄ

issue.title: fix: handle NaN and Infinity float values in gRPC

labels.name: documentation-needed
labels.description: A PR which will need a separate PR for documentation

repository.name: k6
repository.description: A modern load testing tool, using Go and JavaScript

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Fixes (?): https://github.com/grafana/k6/issues/3990

The problem was in this specific line:

https://github.com/grafana/k6/blob/a74d8039a2be85a7f24199f92ae1680426ee44d7/internal/js/modules/k6/grpc/client.go#L363

This `MarshalJSON` implemented in Sobek uses a copy of [JSON.stringify()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/JSON/stringify) under the hood, and per [JSON RFC](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7159#page-7), neither `Infinity` or `NaN` as values are accepted as valid numbers.

However, since we rely on ProtoJSON, which [does support special strings](https://protobuf.dev/programming-guides/json/
) `"Infinity"` and `"NaN"`, I guess that the idea would be to "normalize" them as a string format before marshaling, which is what this PR implements.
